subject: RE: [junit] Code coverage analysis with JUnit
msgSnippet: I ve been using EMMA for quite a while.  When I chose it in early 2004, the landscape of open source coverage tools was pretty sparse.  I evaluated EMMA,
messageBody:
I've been using EMMA for quite a while. When I chose it in early 2004, the landscape of open source coverage tools was pretty sparse. I evaluated EMMA, jcoverage, and groboutils. At that time JCoverage didn't work well for us -- it couldn't handle our large codebase. Groboutils was slooow.

EMMA was fast, had good docs, was easy to integrate into our ant build scripts, and had responsive support. The reports are "OK"; I like clover's better, but did not want to pay $$$. Having said that, the reports are good enough for us and provide a green/yellow/red line-based view of your java source files showing what lines were fully/partially/non executed. The ant tasks provide easy customization of the reports.

I recommend EMMA highly.

I've not looked at cobertura.

John

-----Original Message-----
From: jason r tibbetts [mailto:tibbettj@...]
Sent: Thursday, February 23, 2006 7:53 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Code coverage analysis with JUnit


Anderson John-QA2554 wrote:
>
> Has anyone integrated and used JUnit and EMMA on a large scale
> commercial product? If so, were you satisfied with EMMA as a code
> coverage analysis tool?
>
> Is there a better open source code coverage analysis tool available that
> works with JUnit?
>
> Are there a better commercial code coverage analysis tools available
> that work with JUnit?

I've used the GPL'd jcoverage, cobertura (a more up-to-date rewrite of
jcoverage), and EMMA. Of the three, I prefer cobertura for its clean
layout. EMMA's output looks quite clunky, even though it does provide a
bit more information than the other two.
